title: Microsoft argues email stored in Ireland not subject to search warrant
text:
1 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Microsoft lawyers argued in court Wednesday that a U.S. search warrant can't be used to force tech companies to turn over emails and other information stored on servers outside of the United States.
The case is being heard in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York City.
Microsoft is appealing a ruling against it in 2014, when U.S. District Judge Loretta Preska ruled the company has to hand over email stored on its servers in Ireland to comply with a U.S. warrant in a narcotics case.
The emails in question were stored in Dublin at a data center used for some of Microsoft's customers outside of the United States.
Microsoft and other tech companies say that email stored on computer servers overseas can't be obtained through warrants because warrants don't reach outside of the United States.
The court battle is part of an ongoing issue in the tech world over who has jurisdiction over users' data, at a time when it could be stored anywhere in the world.
The appeals court's questions Wednesday focused primarily on whether the most important issue was where the email was stored — in Ireland, or where it would eventually be disclosed — in the United States, said Craig Newman, a data privacy lawyer and expert with the law firm of Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler in New York City, who attended the hearing.
Preska said in 2014 that because the servers are run by Microsoft, a U.S. company, where they are located doesn't matter.
The appeals court asked who owned the contents of an email and whether there was less expectation of privacy for email that for other types of communication.
Microsoft's argument is that the government needs to use diplomatic means, set out in the Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty between Ireland and the United States, to access the information.
The case is part of a broad push by the tech industry to get lawmakers to update laws that govern data stored in the cloud. "The cloud" refers to information that isn't stored on a customer's computer, but on servers that could be anywhere in the world, accessible via the internet.
"Today's Microsoft argument brought into focus the difficult decision facing the appellate court. It's not just about privacy or respect for the laws of other countries, but how a law passed in 1986 — before email, instant messaging and social media — should now be applied in a digital world where communications and technologies continue to evolve," said Newman.
If American companies can't protect customer privacy for information stores elsewhere, the concern is that foreign companies that can make a privacy promise and stay outside the jurisdiction of U.S. law enforcement could take business away from them.
